description.text:
The Sphero Programming Home Base enables pupils to program the Sphero robot accurately across a track. The Base helps the Sphero to have a fixed starting point at the beginning of the track and a steady direction. This makes it possible for the pupils to repeatedly test and further develop their program. A simple solution with a great impact.

With the aid of the SPRK Lightning Lab app of Sphero it is possible to program the track for the Sphero. This is a very attractive way of learning how to program. In order to let the robot roll to the end of the track successfully, the pupils have to test, evaluate and adapt their program several times. It is of great importance that each of the attempts the robot has the same starting position and is aimed in the same direction. The slightest difference in position or direction will have great consequences for the program from the first meters and curves on. With the Sphero Programming Home Base the pupils can put the robot in the exact same starting point and aim it right. The Sphero Programming Home Base can easily be taped or fixed on the start of the track.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

20%

Notes:

To reduce printing time, restrict wall thickness to a maximum of 0.6 mm.

To design a Home Base was a real challenge. It had to give the Sphero enough support to let it rotate around its own axis when aiming it, but also had to be a platform the Sphero could easily roll off from. After having designed, printed and tested six prototypes, I finally succeeded in finding the right balance. I also had to look for a suitable and accurate way to calibrate the Sphero aiming light.

Overview:
Developing a program by which the Sphero can roll across a track is a good and easy way to help pupils to learn how to program. The Sphero Programming Home Base enables them to develop and test complex programs in an accurate way.

Objectives:
Pupils are able to develop program the robot across a track. In this way they can be introduced to computational thinking, geometrical shapes and milliseconds, and so forth.

Audiences:
Suitable for pupils from 8 to 14 years old. By alternating the complexity of the track this activity can be challenging for several age ranges. Younger pupils in particular learn in a ‘trial and error’ kind of way. The Sphero Programming Home Base makes this kind of learning possible.

Subjects:
Math, Science, Robotics, IT

Standards:

Standards (Dutch primary education)

  • Teaches pupils to create a reusable algorithm
  • Teaches pupils to evaluate multiple algorithms
  • Teaches pupils to solve problems by formulating a specific set of instructions
  • Helps pupils to detect and solve defects, also called ‘debugging’.

Lesson/Activity:

Instruction

  • Tell the pupils they are going to write a program that makes the Sphero follow the track and which skills they learn by doing this.
  • Show them briefly what kind of codes they can use to do so. Keep it short to offer the pupils the possibility of discovering the process for themselves.
  • Explain the pupils how to connect the tablet with their robot.
  • Explain how the Sphero Home Base functions and why it is so helpful.

Activity

  • Have the pupils work in pairs or triads. Two groups can work at a track at the same time when they use the track in opposite ways.
  • When groups are finished with one track they can move on to the next.

Evaluation

  • Let the pupils tell what difficulties they encountered and what went well. Have them think of ways to improve the process. Ask the pupils what they have learned from this.

Extra challenge

  • Develop cyclical tracks and let the pupils write a program with a loop by which the robot can keep rolling across the track.
  • Let several groups write a program for the same track. Time both programs at the end of the lesson to see which program is the fastest way to let the robot race the track.
  • Anonymize the developed programs and let the pupils without tablet or robot consider which program belongs to which track.

Duration:
The total duration of the lesson is one hour and a half max, of which fifteen minutes is instruction, one hour is activity and fifteen minutes is evaluation. It is the battery duration of the Sphero Robot that makes an end to the lesson, not the involvement of the pupils! That is why the maximum duration for activity is one hour.

Preparation:

  • Install the SPRK Lightning Lab app on all the tablets and make sure the Sphero robots are all fully loaded.
  • Tape the track on the floor. Tape the Sphero Programming Home Base on the starting point of the track. Older pupils can also make and tape a track by themselves.

References
https://sprk.sphero.com/
http://www.sphero.com/education
https://itunes.apple.com/nl/app/sprk-lightning-lab-programming/id1017847674
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.sphero.sprk

Rubric & Assessment:
At the end of the project the pupils will have written their own program. By using one SPRK-account the programs can be examined and compared on one tablet. Examine if the robot can reach the end of the track while staying in between the lines with the developed program. Also evaluate the collaboration of the pupils during the project.
VW Aschenbecher / VW Ashtray

description.text: This project was designed to help students learn the placement of all of the elements on the Periodic Table. I wanted to design something that would give childen a more hands on fun and way to learn all of the elements. I saw online that there where four new elements added to the Periodic Table of Elements and thought that an Elements "puzzle" would be perfect to design for this challenge. I did not have time to print the whole project and still enter in time but I did do two test prints that show that everything will work, last two pictures.

pieces:
For every every piece I used the text tool in 123d design and wrote the abbreviation for the element that the piece would become. I would then use the extrusion tool to give the text a third dimension. After that i would center the text in the middle of the piece then move it up and use it as a cutting tool to add the text to the piece. I continued this process for ever element.

Board:
I first design the shape of the board.I then made a copy of all the pieces and scaled them up to 1.05 and used the pieces as a cutting tool to add the holes for the pieces. After that i added the text to the top. Finally i used the sketch tool to draw a dovetail design that i would then use to cut the board in half giving the board dovetail joints to connect the two pieces after printing.

Project Name:

Periodic Table of Elements Puzzle

Overview & Background:

In this project students will learn the placement of all of the elements along with (if the teacher chooses to) how to wright chemical bonds and how to find the number of valence electrons each element has.

Objectives:

Students should expect to learn all things listed above plus anything in the school curriculum that could be tought using this project

Audiences:

This project would be appropriate for grades 8 and above

Subjects:

This project should be used in the subject science

Skills Learned (Standards):

After completion of this project students should have gained certain skills such as knowing the abbreviation for each element

Lesson/Activity:

Each day of this project the teacher should assign a group or number of elements that should be learned that day. The students should then get a set length of hands on time to work on the group of elements assigned

Duration:

The duration of this project should be about 1 to 2 weeks depending on what all the teacher/school decides to teach

Preparation:

Before starting this project students should have learned what all the different groups of elements are (metals, non-metals, noble gases)

References:

Students should use the picture below as a reference

Rubric & Assessment:

At the end of this project students should have learned the placement of all of the elements on the periodic table of elements

Handouts & Assets:

Teachers could print and hand out the periodic table above but that should not be used well practicing

This is a fully parametric stand for small screwdrivers and similar tools.

This version has 6x5 holes and fits the "Wiha PicoFinish" line of tools.

It's however fully customizable on Onshape

Description of the Onshape customization options:
The geometry is controlled entirely by the 4 variables at the top of the features list.
The number of tool holders is controlled bey the "#holes_per_row" and "#holes_per_column" variables.
"#holes_per_row" is practically unlimited.
"#holes_per_column" only works in a range of 1 - 10

The other two variables "#hole_diam_top" and "#hole_diam_bottom" are used to control the size and taper of the tool holder holes. The default sizes of 12 and 9 are a good fit for the "Wiha PicoFinish" line of tools.

title: Internal filament guide for Printrbot direct drive extruder

description.text: This replaces a small wood part in the extruder assembly and creates a guide between the drive gear and the hot end, eliminating jams inside the extruder.  This fits the direct drive extruder upgrade (I bought it in October, 2013) that Printrbot sells for all models of their printers.

Print this part.  Remove the lower front 3 mm screw holding your extruder together and remove the small wooden piece that forms the front of the filament channel between the drive gear and the hotend.  Replace with this printed part.  Check to see that the hole in the guide lines up with the hole in the hotend using some filament.  The 3 mm screw hole came out tight on mine.  It may help to ream this hole with a drill bit.  The filament hole should be good for 1.75 mm filament without any rework.

comments.text: I did have to do quite a bit of filing on the end with the filament tube as it pushed against the other wood piece. I ended up filing the screw hole sideways some as well to get it to fit. Still, this is much better than the stock setup.
comments.author: SFarbo

print_settings.Notes:: Be sure you print this so that the bottom surface is flat and smooth!  A glass or other smooth build plate is perfect.  On my MakerBot Replicator, I use a raft to create a flat bottom.

description.text: Just attach "removable" adhesive wall hanger strips to the bottom surface, and place on the wall where you want the picture centered. Allow for the frame width to the top edge of the canvas. Be sure the wall surface is clean as well as the bottom surface of the hanger smooth and flat, and that you keep the top edge level. Wait the recommended time before hanging the canvas. On mine I put a small strip of 80 grit sandpaper to create a better grip on the wood edge of the frame. Simple, cheap, and reusable! Do not exceed the rated weight of the adhesive strips! Most of my canvas prints weigh under 1 pound. BTW my hanger is level but the camera angle for the photo was not!

description.text:
I created this replacement part for my electric grass trimmer. It fixes trimmer spool and if pushed it allows release of synthetic rope.
Better print it using hit resistive material like ABS, HIPS, so on to make it more durable.
This screw button has 10.4 mm hole for 10mm shaft of trimmer and holds M13 screw. Original button also has 17.5mm (size is updated) steel cover. The button is enforced a little bit since printed parts are usually less durable than extruded one under pressure.
Note: version 2 updates diameter of steel cover 17->17.5mm to better match its real size.

title: Sturdy Extended Feet for Logitech Classic Keyboard

description.text: This is an extended keyboard foot (1 cm longer than the flippy feet) for a Logitech Classic 200 keyboard. Each foot is mounted with one small plastic screw, so they are sturdy and still can be removed.

Printer:

Installation

You'll need two small plastic screws, and two holes on the keyboard's bottom. Mine has small plastic drain holes (?), and one of these is perfect for mounting a foot. I had to drill a hole on the other end, just deep enough for the screw.

The foot should sit with the base on the frame, and the longer leg down in the "excavation."

comments.author: saavik24

comments.text:
Hello,
Thank you for these models. May I ask you some questions on this set of yours, as I am currently trying to implement it?
I believe you have used PLA for the print, right? I attempted to use ABS (I had nothing else at that moment, and, being a total newbie, had only theoretical information about the printing material), which revealed at least two issues.
First, all round parts were printed as oval-shaped. In your opinion, is it caused by the type of plastic used, or is it just my (eventual) lack of skill when setting up and calibrating the printer?
Second, there appears to be a problem about the size of the final parts owing to the contraction. From what I read, I know that ABS prints shrink (at a rate up to 8%). To cope with that, I set the model scale at 1.08 in Cura. How do you deal with the size issue, if you do?
Overall, is it OK to use ABS for that (i.e. upgrades)? Can it be that I am just using the plastic which is not appropriate for the task?
Thanks!

title: Solar Radiation Shield (Stevenson Screen) for Outdoor Thermometer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a solar radiation shield for mounting a temperature sensor outdoors. The shield allows air to flow through freely, but protects the thermometer from direct and reflected solar radiation. This provides a much more accurate temperature reading during daylight hours.

The shield consists of several parts:

  • Several rings that are open in the middle for sensor equipment
  • Solid plates to shield the top and bottom
  • A larger top plate to provide extra shade and room for batteries or other non-sensor electronics
  • A small plastic tripod that fits under the top plate to provide locations to zip-tie wires, batteries, chargers, etc.
  • Solar cell mounting brackets
  • An internal grid to secure sensors
  • Pole mounting plates for various pole configurations

Stuff I used in this build:

  • eSun White ABS filament (1.75mm): Amazon
  • Valspar gloss white plastic spray paint: Amazon
  • WeMos D1 Mini ESP8266 microcontroller: AliExpress
  • Samsung 18650 lithium battery: eBay
  • Lithium battery charge controller: eBay
  • 1W 6V Solar Panel: eBay
  • DHT22 digital temperature and humidity sensor: eBay
  • 6-32 threaded rod: Amazon
  • 6-32 wing nuts: Amazon
  • Micro Deans battery connector: eBay
  • 3/4" square aluminum tubing: Amazon
  • Scotch Extreme Mounting Tape: Amazon

My weather station is on-line and you can view the data on ThingSpeak here: https://thingspeak.com/channels/144231

When you click on these links and make a purchase, it can result in commissions from eBay and Amazon that help support my work.

Printer:

MakerFarm Prusa i3v

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Support material can help with the shallow radii at the edges of the plates, but is not strictly necessary, depending on your printer.

Assembly

To assemble the screen, I used 6-32 threaded rod. M3 threaded rod will also work. I heat-set threaded inserts into the top plate, screwed in pieces of 6-32 rod, stacked all of the parts on the rods and secured with stainless steel wing nuts. An alternate version of the top plate is provided that can be tapped for M3 (or 6-32) rod if you don't have the inserts. Just drill out the holes, tap and screw the rods into the plastic directly.

The triangular part with legs is an electronics mount. It fits in the top cover and provides a place to zip-tie the electronics.

The solar cell mounts are designed so you can mount a solar cell with double-sided foam tape. I recommend Scotch Extreme Mounting Tape.

Wire Routing

If you use this in a wireless solar configuration like I did, you will need to route wires from the solar cell to the charger and batteries under the top and from the batteries to the electronics inside the screen. You can drill holes to pass the wires and seal them with an appropriate sealant, or you can just route the wires over the side and between the layers of the screen.

Fusion 360 Project

If you'd like the original Fusion 360 project, you can view and download it here:

http://a360.co/2wEZE7D

title: Dryer Door Handle - Whirlpool electric dryer #WED5000DW2

description.text:
2017-02-03
Added Bolt On version. Depending on filament type the original design may not be strong enough for repeated use.

2016-08-13
This is a direct replacement for Whirlpool Electric Dryer Door Handle part number W10714516. The part also fits certain dryers manufactured under the Kenmore (Sears) brand.

I replaced the Door Handle with OEM produced part several times but in each case the Door Handle failed in a few month's time.

Printer:

XYZprinting Davinci 1.0 Pro/E3DV6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Supports only reguired under the two tongs that overhang.

Recommend using ABS or PTEG for maximum strength.
Some light sanding of the surface may be desirable depending on the printer resolution and material.

Added Strength

All the tabs were increased in width and the bottom tangs, which were previously hollow, are now solid.

And additional a long latch was added to the middle of the top row of tabs. The purpose of this latch is to afford positive engagement of the top of the Door Handle with the dryer door.

The Bolt-On version attaches to the door from the inside of the outer door panel. It requires removal of 4 inner door panel screws and the Inner panel to gain access to the inside of the outer panel. Use the following hardware:

  • https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009OK22RG
  • https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GDYDS9W

author: MatNow

title: Secondary mirror mount for trackball telescope

description.text:
This is an attempt to make a secondary mirror mount for a trackball telescope, specifically Jerry Oltion's design. The original Oltion design used a vitamin bottle cut at a 45-degree angle.

It prints in two parts, which should be snapped together to make a ball-and-socket joint. Then thread two 3"-long 8-32 screws through the long holes to contact the bottom of the mirror mount surface, and connect one small spring to provide restoring tension between the mirror mount surface and the main block. Advancing or retracting the screws allows the tilt of the mirror mount surface to be adjusted in two directions to properly align with the eyepiece.

The main block includes two curved holes set at right angles, allowing two wires to be threaded through. These are for attaching to the interior of the secondary cage, forming the "spider" mount.

This is a work-in-progress, and I will add photos of the part fully installed in a trackball telescope once they're available.

title: Easy small compact strong pan tilt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have tried many pan&tilt systems on here but non of them gave me strong and easy fitting parts.
So I decided to make my own.

  • Its easy to assemble (If not let me know!!! I can change it).
  • Different options for you to chose.
  • Compact design.

Parts needed to compleet:

  • M3x10 Screw
  • 2x 9gram Servo

Optional parts:

  • M3 ring.
  • M3x4 Press-nut

Tools needed:
Screwdriver
Hotglue-gun or other glue if you don't like that.

Instructions:
(every photo is a step)

1) (Optional) insert M3x4 Press-nut in Part C
2) Glue servo in Part A1 (or A2 if you like that mount)
3) Glue servo horn in Part B. (don't glue it up side down)
sand down flush if needed.
4) Put the servo horn on the servo (Don't forget to center your servo's)
5) Glue Part C on Part B
6) insert the servo screw
7) Glue the second servo in Part C
8) Glue the small servo horn in part D1 (Or part D2 if that fits you camera better)
9) Glue Part E over the servo horn
10) Put the servo wire over the servo and put Part D on the servo.
(if the servo is centered Part D should be angled up a bit)
11) Now go to the other side of Part D and put (Optional: a M3 ring in between Part C and D) M3x10 screw inside
This must be a little lose as this part should move.
12) Go back and put the servo screw in the servo.
And your done!.

Thanks for making and please let me know wen it isn't working for you!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

No

No

0.3

25

I used a 0.6 nozzle and a layer hide of 0.3.
This gives me fast prints but you can choose what you want.

title: Rose Quartz's Sword from Steven Universe!

description.text:
Buy one here: http://etsy.me/2cvlCAl

Check out our Etsy for all of our 3D printed awesomeness!
https://www.etsy.com/shop/CarryTheWhat

Rose Quartz's sword from Steven Universe! This is a remix of a design by dorito_for_her which we thought was super cool!

This version has been split into multiple segments that can be printed 3 simple colors; pink, purple, and white! With just a little painting, this sword looks AWESOME!

The pictures have the old version of the purple handle without the raised detail that can be painted, the new included .STL is the detailed version seen in the video!

Use some super glue to hold the pieces together, and have fun printing!

Check out a build video by Andrew Sink: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhOUgLJdn7A&t=4s

description.text:
So, this might not be interesting for most people, but anyway.

I have a special keyring for my motorcycle key (and other keys as well). It is a small metal brick with a number on it, that is registered at the local police. If I loose my keys and someone finds them, they can be traced and returned to me.

The metal brick is 16mm x 52mm with rounded ends (r=8mm) and is 2mm thick.

Problem is that the steering stem on a motorcycle is easy to damage with a metal keychain. :(

So I came up with this little "sleeve" that encapsules the little metal brick yet makes it easy to read the text on it. :)

Attached are also files to open in 123Design if you want to fiddle with this...

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

At 3.9mm height, pause the print and insert the metal brick in the void. The rest of the print will print over and encapsule it inside.

(I also changed color of the filament to make it look fast and sporty. :)
Support for charge module on KIS3R33S base

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Module v2 filter adapter

description.text:
UPDATE Fixed the sideways mounting plate (I hope). Dimensions of the camera board are so close in x and y I got them mixed up. Sorry :(

small update: Added the raspberry pi camera module model

v1.11 adds the ability to change the offset (how far the filter sits away from the camera board) via the "offset" variable

Mount for a Raspberry Pi camera module v2 to hold a regular camera filter or piece of glass.

This isn't designed to be air tight, water tight, light tight or protect the camera from dust, rain, snow, humidity or be protective in any way shape or form.

What it will do is allow you to put glass or something in front of the camera to add colour filters, bokeh shapes (if that's even possible with a rpi camera), whatever your heart desires (within reason).

There's no tripod mount or hotshoe mount or any other kind of mount but the openscad file is included so adding your own mounts and brackets is a snap. I didn't include one because I don't yet know how I want this thing mounted (tripod or free standing, etc).

Printer:

dodgy thing I made myself out of random bits and pieces

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1920 x 1080

Infill:

yes

Notes:

Print using Simplify3d using multiple processes or slic3r with modifier meshes.

Print the greeny-blue part (seen when pressing F5 in openscad) at 0.3 or worse and print the bluey part at 0.15 or better to add more resolution to the little teethy bits that grab the filter.

You could try printing the entire thing at 0.15 or 0.3, just means at lower layer heights it'll take longer and larger ones the sticky outey teeth might not be so well defined.

The overhangs are pretty over hangy so I used supports, you may get away without them if your printer is better than mine is.

Sand the outside, remove all the support gunk (if used) prime and paint the entire thing with primer / spray putty (automotive stuff) / sealer / matte black paint to help seal it and protect it from the sunlight.

Description (EN):

This tool helps you to change propellers at an FPV quadcopter. It fits to the normal M5 Nut and to the aerodynamic capping nuts. But thats not all, it includes also an bodel opener for the drink after fly event and you can use it as a guide to shorten your propellers to the size of 4" and 5". So have fun and dont forget: "Don't drink and fly". your Team Airster

Beschreibung (DE):

Dieses Tool hilft dir Propeller auf einer FPV quadcopter zu wechseln. Es passt für die normalen M5 Muttern aber auch für die aerodynamischen Hutmuttern. Aber das ist noch nicht alles, es enthält auch einen Flaschenöffner für das "Chillen nach dem Fliegen" und du kannst es zum kürzen von Propellern auf die Größe von 4 "und 5" verwenden. Also, viel Spaß und nicht vergessen: "Don't drink and fly". dein Team Airster

Just a simple enclosure for an FTDI USB serial adapter (not the Sparkfun version which has a SMD connector soldered to the bottom) that I picked up from Amazon.

I looked through what was already here and the styles were either a bit bulky or didn't seem to match my particular board.

Nothing fancy here. The enclosure snaps together (glue it if you'd like) and helps provide a strain relief for the serial header. It is designed so that the 3.3V/5V jumper is above the enclosure enough to pull it out.

I have included the sketchup file in case you wish (or need) to tweak it.

Note: On my board, I needed to trim the leads on the bottom. You could modify it to accommodate the leads by making it a bit deeper and placing a ridge inside. Up to you.

title: Adjustable/Rotating Mount for Raspberry Pi Camera V2

description.text:
I made this mount to attach the Raspberry Pi Camera V2 on my 3D printer for OctoPrint.
My printer is made of acrylic sheet as an Ultimaker. You can use double-sided adhesive tape or some glue to attach the mount to the printer.

This mount is rotating on 2 axis so you can orient the camera!

If you printed it, please click on "I made one" and upload a photo!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Ulticampy 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print all the files in the given orientatiuon.
You need to add supports to print "Back cover.stl" and "Arm.stl".

Requirements

2x M3x14 screws
2x M3 washers
2x M3 nuts
Some glue
Double-sided adhesive tape (or glue)

Assembly

Pass the cable of the Pi Cam 2 through the front cover and connect it to the camera.
Put the Pi Camera V2 into the front cover.
Assemble the front cover and the back cover by using some glue.
Assemble the back cover, the arm and the mount with the screws, the washers, and the nuts.
Apply some glue or double-sided adhesive on the mount and glue it on your printer.
Orient the camera as you want!

description.text:
I've been working on this one for a bit, and I figured what better day to share this than on election day!

I thought this would be a fun, little desk ornament to show how you're able to handle it while everything else is "going up in flames".

If this looks familiar, it's because it's based off the webcomic attached below. That being said the proportions of the dog are a little odd since I wanted it to match up with the comic strip.

Also, as a heads up, this is a pretty big model, so don't be afraid to scale it down to print.

Enjoy!

As per usual, I just worked off the comic strip image to bring this little guy to life.

Reference Image

description.text:
I needed a pinky grip extension for my M&P Shield 7 Round magazine. So using the existing end cap, I modeled & designed a pinky grip extension.

V2 has a less "aggressive" look to the part. More blending & smoother curves/ larger arcs on the corners.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

I took apart my existing magazine end cap and placed it on my scanner (paper printer). I then took that 2D scan and modeled the perimeter of the end cap. I used a pair of calipers to take the measurements of various interfaces and thicknesses.

I then printed an identical copy of the "short" end cap to verify the dimensions before modifying it to a pinky extension.

After 3-4 tries everything clicked perfectly, so I went and added the pinky extension feature. Works perfectly for my M&P Shield 7 round mag.

title: Modular Screw, Nut and Bolt Drawers on a Rotating Base

description.text:
A modular drawer system for small parts.
Little drawers that slide in and out of a frame that can be clipped together on a rotating base.
The drawer units van be stacked on top of one another, reducing the footprint of the drawer system.

The sides need to be printed one as is, and one mirrored on the x axis.

Once assemble some glue can be added in the joints for extra strength.

I use it to store all my M4 nuts and bolts at the moment.
Will be perfect for all my Meccano toys!

Added the bearing and base, as well as some photos showing assembly. I used 4.5mm bb gun bullets as ball bearings.

description.text: Here is my wall mounted bedside lamp, which my wife insists should be called Pinochio. It's made for a single 12 V LED with a G4 socket. Choose one that does not get too hot!

Printer:

GEEETech i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

15 %

Notes:

Printing the stick and the lamp base is very straight forward. No support structures are needed as long as you print the base face down. Printing the lamp is a bit more tricky. I needs support structure for the lamp hinge, and for the socket mount inside the lamp, but it should only have support structures touching the build plate, not internal support. Make sure the support structure is properly alligned. I made this using wood filament, and then cranked up and down the printing temp. from 205 to 245 C to get the wood like structure. If you make it using ABS you probably would need a brim and a good adhersive to keep it down. I printed the stick in ABS, and quickly brushed with acetone after polishing to give it a shiny look

To make it you will need some parts.

One G4 socket like this:

http://www.ebay.com/bhp/g4-bulb-socket

One 1P ON-ON miniature switch like this:

http://www.ebay.com/itm/20-x-AC-125V-3A-ON-ON-2-Position-1P2T-SPDT-3-Pins-Miniature-Toggle-Switch-Blue-/

And 3 plastic "things" fix the wire going in and out of the lamp (whatever they are called). I suppose you can print something for that also, but I didn't.

print_settings.Notes:: Print slow and not too hot or you'll get some deformation.

description.text:
Never liked the idea of using bulldog clips for holding my heated bed, I'm losing like 10-15mm print area because of them, and after I added a fan shroud, I've had a few times the duct ends got cought in the clips while printing the first layer and was close to a disaster. The one's I saw around here didn't fit my bed, cause my glass is longer on one side (200mm x 214mm), so I made these.

Update 1(8/14/16): The ones I originally uploaded came out a bit to small on the sides and the glass moves around a bit. I remade them in SCAD so you can customize it to fit your bed. Just run the Customizer App and play around with the settings until you get it to fit and hold your bed down tight.

Update 2(8/14/16): I took out the STL since the default settings in Customizer will generate the exact thing I uploaded in the STL and it might not fit your bed and I don't want you to print something that does not work quite well :)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print slow and not too hot or you'll get some deformation.

Designed it using Autodesk Fusion 360.
Then remade in OpenSCAD to use with the Customizer App.

This project will give the students the basics to create their own water fountain. This model is an example of what you can create with this project. The project can easily be manipulated for different skill levels from beginners to experts. The project will provide the students with a list of materials that they will need along with information on how to incorporate them into their fountain.

Note: I have not been able to print the complete fountain because my printer ran out of filament and I do not have any money to buy more.

Desgining

I designed my fountain using two different softwares first I made the general shape of the fountain in 123Design. I formed the bottom collection pool, water path, and the top collection pool with 123Design. I then put the model into Meshmixer to make the model look more organic.

Note

It’s important when designing your fountain to get detailed measurements of the connectors, tubes, and pump to make sure it will all fit in properly.

Overview & Background

The students will learn how to design around objects with set dimensions.

Objectives

How to build from set dimensions, how to make models look more organic, and how to hook up simple electronics.

Audiences

This project can be adapted for ages as young as 14. This project can also be used for experts looking for a new challenge.

Subjects

This project covers subjects such as Engineering, Art, and Electrics.

Skills Learned

Students will learn how to properly measure objects, how to sculpt using Meshmixer, and how to hook up simple electronics.

Lesson/Activity

1) Decide on the basics of your design.
2) Measure the pump and tube connectors that are provided.
3) Start designing the fountain; start with the bottom collection pool and work up.
4) Keep the shape and details simple for now.
5) Once the students have a rough design they need to import it into Meshmixer.
6) The students will use Meshmixer to make the fountain look more organic.
7) Once the students are satisfied with their work it needs to be printed, I recommend using abs (with my model I had to break it into three parts).
8) If the model needed to be broken into multiple parts then the student will need to put them together using abs slurry.
9) Once the model is whole the students should go about installing the tube connectors.
10) Once the tube connectors are installed the motor can be hooked up, I used an Arduino Uno because I plan on hooking up led lights to it. The other option is using a transformer. If an Arduino is used simply plug the wires from the pump into the positive and negative into the Arduino. If a transformer is used the student will need to solder the transformer to the pump.
11) Then plug the intake of the pump to the tube connector on the bottom collection pool, and the output of the pump to the top collection pool.
12) Now to prime the pump the student will need to put water in the top collection pool and let it flow down into the pump, they should also fill the bottom collection pool with water.
13) The last step is to paint the fountain.

Duration

This section depends on how difficult the student’s projects are. The fountain I created took me about eight hours to design, 1 hr to put together, and 2 days to print. It would take about 2 weeks for students to complete it.

Preparation

They should have a simple understanding of CAD software.

Rubric & Assessment

By the end of the project the students should have designed a fountain that can hold water without leaks or spills, collects it in one place, and transport it to another place. The projects should be grades not only on functionality, but also on the student’s ability to make it look organic using Meshmixer.

author: MrUnicorn

title: Vertical Wind Turbine VAWT
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Vertical Axis Wind Turbine VAWT

A beautiful wind turbine (Ø245mm x 800mm). Intended for balcony and low windspeed use.

Designed for my Ultimaker 2+ (max build volume, big nozzle, high printspeed).
Of course you can print it on every, big enough printer. I recommend to use a big nozzle (0.6mm for „Flügel 8x.stl“ with Vase Mode, 0.8mm for the rest)



short video: https://youtu.be/4xszhV_X3DU

___
update
12/11/2017:

added the STEP files!

12/01/2018:

a smaller Version with a diameter of 130mm here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2755208

___


What you need

1x . . . . . . . M8x1000mm straight threaded rod

8x . . . . . . . M8 nut

2x . . . . . . . 608 bearing Ø22xØ8x7mm (e.g. inline skates bearings)

2x . . . . . . . bolt and nut (e.g.M4 x20)

1x . . . . . . . pipe or stick Ø12,15..., 30mm (print „Lager Ø..2x.stl” with the same diameter)

2x . . . . . . . paper clip to use them as a cotter

~820g . . . . Filament



Print settings
„Flügel 8x.stl“

PETG
Spiral Mode/Vase Mode----0.6mm Nozzle----0.3mm Layer----65mm/s Speed
There is a GCODE for the Ultimaker 2 /2+

„Achse 4x.stl“

PETG
Spiral Mode/Vase Mode----0.8mm Nozzle----0.4mm Layer----65mm/s Speed

other parts

PETG
0.8mm Nozzle----0.2-0.4 Layer----40-75mm/s Speed----Infill 15%



  • There are two calibration files, the two parts should fit smoothly together.

    „Testfile Unterteil 0.8mm“ for print settings of the parts „Unterteil1x“ „Zwischenteil3x“ „Oberteil1x“. The part has a internal width of around 2mm.

    „Testfile Flügel spiral mode 0.6mm“ for the settings of „Flügel 8x.stl“. The part should have a width of 1.1- 1.5mm.




Assembly instruction
  • Assembly instruction can be found under this link: https://youtu.be/cVetrYLIKok
  • It is important to use a straight threaded rod.


if you have any suggestions for improvement, questions or need further information, feel free to contact me.

Gerne auch auf Deutsch :-)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

comments.text: My latest print of the VAWT is mounted on a 5-foot long galvanized iron pipe which is bolted to my outside deck using a closet flange.  It spin effortlessly...friends have accused me of having mounted a hidden motor to make it turn!  After more than two months outside, through rain, ice and some very high winds, it continues to work flawlessly.  A neighbor who is a dentist asked me to print him one of these to mount outside of one of his operatories...it has been a huge hit for him, his staff, and most important, his patients.  They focus on the VAWT during dental procedures which reduces anxiety in most of them.  Another neighbor, an engineer who recently started working from home, told me he frequently goes outside and stares at the turbine while thinking about design challenges; he said it's like watching a waterfall.  Another friend commented that the spinning turbine is downright sensuous!  He's right.  So thank you again, Tobias, for this design.  It has made my whole 3D printing experience worthwhile and purposeful.  Way more so than the hundreds of trinkets I've printed and subsequently thrown away.  More precisely states, that my wife has thrown away!

description.text:
WARNING! These models are not suitable for real world use out of the box as a 3D printed item. They may be OK with a non-igniting payload, but paired with an igniting payload they would be unsafe as the models tend to break apart near the base. A better though untested option would be using these printed models to make a mold and then casting the models using a more suitable material.

Remember keep your hands off the chamber area/barrel when firing 37mm flare launchers and stay safe with your loads! Use these designs at your own risk! I accept 0% responsibility for their use or misuse. 3d printed materials tend to be weak and it may be dangerous to actually use 3d printed parts in this manner, making molds and castings based off these prints may be a better option. Use at your own discretion. These are only here to help people in the hobby. It may be best to just use the cardboard tubes available and a bit of hot glue to affix one of these end caps to the top for looks, such as the hollow or flat. It would be similar to people preparing normal cardboard tubes and affixing an easter egg to the top. Be safe!

This is intended as an easily customized 3D printable payload cup designed for 37mm flare launchers. They are intended as non firearm parts for a 37mm flare launcher, intended payloads would be making fireworks using flying fish or crackling fuse, smoke with proper vent holes drilled by end user, or OC containers. Please observe and follow all local and federal laws regarding 37mm reloading, remember you are not allowed to create any anti personnel rounds without first registering your launcher as a DestructiveDevice so be careful with your combination of printed parts/payloads chosen. I suggest registering your 37mm as a DD if you intend to be reloading any unique projectiles just so you won't have to worry about it. I am unsure how actually printing and using some of the end caps could be viewed legally though they are very similar to those commercially available. Stay within the boundaries of the law!

The OD of the cup is 1.297" and the ID is 1". It was designed to be used with rubber bands wrapped around the base and where it contacts top of shell to stabilize it or tape may be used. Just make sure its not tighter than a slip fit, you don't want any chance of it getting stuck in the hull. If using a burst charge for pyrotechnic loads, make sure there is plenty of time for fuse and that the empty space between bottom of payload cup and burst cup is filled with glue or somehow completely isolated from the lift charge, you do not want the lift charge to set off the burst charge accidentally if something fails. In other words if it is unsafe to go off in your barrel it is probably unsafe to load in these payload cups. Making molds of these and casting is a much better idea than using straight out of the box 3D printed parts.

It should fit the reloadable shells by:
exoticammo.com
exotic-firearms.com
americanspecialtyammo.com
reloadableshells.com

Fit on these can be adjusted with some tape or rubber bands near the base but be sure not to make your projectile too tight in the shell. Also if you print the models at 92% scale then it should fit the screw apart shells by MLR Distributing. You may also print the parts at a larger scale to be closer to a slip fit for your chosen application.

Please TIP if you like this file so I can devote more time to designing similar models!

If you used any support material/rafts etc when printing you may need to clean up the ID of the tube that contacts the support of the end caps. You can use a butter knife sandpaper or a small file, it should not be a chore. You can try printing the end caps nose down to avoid cleanup though the flat end cap or base plates should be printed large face down as the file comes oriented. The parts are a snap fit and aren't meant to come back apart easily, so don't put your end cap on until your ready. I think these parts would be extremely simple to cast once printed.

title: DVD Shelf Speaker Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I decided to sketch up (pun intended) an idea I have been kicking around in my head for a DVD holding shelf that would also work as a speaker stand for my living room sound setup.

The idea was that the shelf could hold DVD cases either upright or on their side (it turns out around 12 standard DVD cases make a nice square block that fits into a 20cm square hole. with finger room to spare.)

The front shelves are 16cm deep, meaning there is just the right amount of depth for DVD cases and box sets. The side shelves are 20 x 20 x 21.5, meaning they are a bit deeper than optimal, but the design was to use 15mm plywood or other standard material to build with, so that's just how it ends up.

I am also considering making the side shelf 41.5cm tall, 20cm wide and 21.5cm deep and use it for something else. Or putting a wood, glass or plexi door on there... Lot's of ideas for this one.

Notes:

This is not intended to be 3D printed, to be honest.

Make Noodles and Noodles of Butter

The Baconlicious Butter Pig Introduced the world to a new die, the Corncob....

And the West Coast Butter Pig introduced us to another one, the Noodle...

But what about those of you who are still using a Butter Pig Classic at the dinner table?

You're in luck! I've remixed the Noodle die to fit the original Butter Pig. The flat version uses Jon's design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1664661 which elimates the rails on one side so they can be printed laying down, but will still fit in a pig that has rails on both sides.

I've also included standing versions of both dies that have rails on both sides, just like the original ones have.

For those of you who've already printed a Baconlicious Butter Pig, this download includes a Noodle die to add to your collection. If you've printed a West Coast Butter Pig, then you already have all the dies.

This download includes both the Noodle and the Corncob dies for the original (Classic) Butter Pig.

Check out the whole Barnyard Family at http://www.thingiverse.com/steveweber314/collections/butter-pig-barnyard-family-of-friends

Video https://youtu.be/MJ3z2VeMv4g

remixed_from.title: One Piece Lm8uu Y-Carriage for Prusa i2

description.text:
This is a version my Lm8uu Y Carriage adapted for the Mendelmax.
Updated y-carriage7_max with working 3 lm8uu design.

I personally use the y-carriage_al version, it has a lowered belt socket on the motor side that keeps the belt level when used with this https://sdp-si.com/eStore/PartDetail.asp?Opener=Group&PartID=60190&GroupID=346) aluminum pulley form SDP. Use y-carriage_flat if you are using a bigger pulley on Y. I no longer believe in bed springs, nor leveling the print bed after the first time. In fact, to maxbot's credit, somehow there seems to be no bed leveling needed at all on my MendelMax. The print bed bolts together perfectly level and stays level so far (touch wood). I printed the spacers out of ABS just in case the platform gets too warm during long printing sessions. Print either the y-carriage_al or y-carriage_flat depending on your need, and then y-carriage_spacer.

title: Twice Lift Improved Propeller
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
32 N of force at 9644 RPM, Four Blades Propeller.
27 N of force at 9644 RPM, Three Blades Propeller.

+++++++++++++++V-3+++++++++++++++
I dragged on that extrusion pattern along the entire blade. What I think that was happened is that now the air moves over the top surface even faster than before and creating much lower pressure. Compared with the best propeller design with the same size that I could find, this propeller generate 400% more lift. According to the simulation, the conventional propeller generate around 7N of lift meanwhile this one generate 22N. Now, personally I don't trust too much in the simulation so until someone (or even me) could make a real prototype and test it, I can't promise anything. I hope helped somebody.
------------------------V-2------------------------
I made some modifications to the model, and the simulation says that the force has increased and the average turbulence has decreased. If someone has any ideas to improve it I'm open to suggestions :D
~~~~~~~V-1~~~~~~~
I design this propeller 3D model in my way and I add some features which improve the thrust and reduce the weight. I ran several flow simulation to determine the efficiency of the propeller, and I was surprised by the result, I expected a much lower thrust. I don't own a 3D printer so I can't print it and make real tests, if anybody wold make it and share his results I will be very grateful.

comments.text: Found it works great on qaudcopters, not so sure for UAVs. I found it really does need a reduced amount of throttle to get off the ground. Very cool what you made here.

author: Johnny1070

description.text: I printed several mounts and finally decided to do one myself. The cross sections are bulky because I got tired of seeing the plastic bending under the weight of the wiring to the print head. This holder has slots on one side to slide the Arduino board into and a spring latch to catch and prevent it from moving out. There is enough friction that it is unlikely to move out but I thought the latch would be a nice feature. It has a mount for a 1.5" fan on the side to keep things cool.

Sketch UP

I do most of my designs on Sketch UP. I fond an Arduino/Ramps assembly in the warehouse and started in designing around it. Beware! All Arduino boards are not the same length. Verify yours and scale the design accordingly. The variations are not much but I found my latch didn't work after printing because there was 1/8" difference in length.

title: Parametric Heavy Duty Binocular Tripod Mount

description.text:
No way to tripod mount your particular binoculars or telescope? This version is for heavier binoculars which need a little extra support, but will still work just fine with smaller, lightweight binoculars.

Simply take the measurements shown in the attached image, and plug them into the "barrel_diameter" and "arm_length" variables. Print, add a 1/4" 20 thread nut, and you're good to go!

Note: You may want to go a little long on the "arm_length" for aesthetic purposes.

Print in the default rotation for best shear strength.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

solid

Notes:

You may or may not need supports for the hole in which the nut will be placed, but it might be a good idea to generate supports just to make sure the hole keeps its shape, enabling the nut to fit properly.

I tried printing with no supports, and it actually worked fine. The hexagonal space for the nut was a bit tight, so I heated my nut on the stove and pushed it into the hole, where it fits nice and tight.

You can find a very cheap trapezoidal threaded rod kit on aliexpress.com typing "thsl-400-8d".

If you decide to use a TR8X2 threaded rod don't forget to set "steps per mm" to Z:400.
Enjoy ;)

Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko nucleus prints conveniently on a flatbed FDM-type machine. This is a remix of thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:529408 which is from the ESA source file: http://blogs.esa.int/rosetta/2014/10/03/measuring-comet-67pc-g

All I did was cut it in half so it can print conveniently on flatbed FDM-type machines, which are very common in many institutions and homes. Glue the two halves together. And don't forget to visit the ESA Rosetta Mission page (http://sci.esa.int/rosetta/14615-comet-67p) and the JPL page (http://www.jpl.nasa.gov) for the folks who track and navigate this most extraordinary mission.

"Crater"-like circular features on the comet are not impact craters. They are holes, some of them deep, from which the cometary ejecta comes. The two lobes of the actual body have very different densities, confirming that they aggregated, and complicating gravitational models used in navigation.

The "selfie" space photograph is from the Rosetta Spacecraft, which itself appears in the field of view, and the comet about 50 km away; see caption here: http://sservi.nasa.gov/articles/rosetta-snaps-selfie-at-comet-67pchuryumov-gerasimenko/

comments.text: I had some trouble printing mine. I am very new to 3D printing as I only started less than 2 weeks ago. I printed 2 of these. One was with ABS and the other with PLA. Both times, I leveled the bed before printing. My problem is that on both prints, the bottom of each end of the clip does not have the properly rounded edge like the top side does. On both prints, each end looks like someone took a bite out of the bottom corner. Otherwise the clip is perfect. The first time it happened, I chalked it up to lack of experience with ABS but when I re-leveled the bed and reprinted with PLA and the same thing happened, I think there must be something else going on. I have looked at your photos and pulled the file into my modeling program and the file looks right. What could I be doing wrong? I will try to post a photo in a moment
comments.author: rodqmiller

comments.text:
Try adding support to your print, and enabling the cooling fan on the 2nd layer onward. When printing the bottom round edge, it's actually over hanging as it prints upwards, so the support helps there. By turning on the cooling fan, it actually causes your edge to solidify faster before it has the opportunity to droop down. You can play with your print speed also.
As long as your print can adhere to your bed the whole time, there shouldn't be any issue with your bed levelness and bed temperature. But take note, when turning on your nozzle cooling fan, the whole temperature dynamics will change and you might need to increase your bed temperature, and/or add brim or raft to counter it.
comments.author: rodqmiller

comments.text: Thanks for your reply. I printed it several times and usually, I did print with support but there are several option and I am still very new. I'm pretty sure I used Brim and support type of "touching buildplate". I have not ever played with the cooling fan option but I checked and it is turned on by default so it was on during the print. My bed temperature for PLA has been set to 70. I had read somewhere that heating the bed was not necessary for PLA and that source said to go down to 50 but I tried printing another project while setting the bed temperature to 50 and I could tell right away it was going to fail because the first layer was not sticking in several places so I moved back to 70 and that has seemed to work. My print speed is and was set to 50 and could go all the way to 150 but I haven't ever changed that yet.Thanks again. I may try it again with a different kind of support. As a newbie, I'm looking at this project and it doesn't look like it would need much if any support except on those corners. Maybe a "touching everywhere" option would be in order.
comments.author: kel

comments.text: I made this the other day & was working great.  Unfortunately on a hot day with the car interior at 40ºC it warped & drooped.  Would recommend making it from something other than PLA.
comments.author: GraphicX

comments.text: yes, ABS would be a better choice. my print with ABS works great under the sun.

title: Helix RH clamp for BPE Pro arrow fletching jig (may suit other jigs as well)

description.text:
This fletching clamp was created for arrows up to 6.1 mm or 0.24" in diameter and for the BPE Pro fletching jig. Whether you shoot target outdoors or hunt, it is beneficial to use thinner arrows. It is designed for vanes up to 2" long, like the Blazer. It puts 2 degrees of right hand helix into the vanes. Helix produces better flight path than offset fletching. It may work with other fletchers as well but you may need to adjust the back angle of the clamp base so it can slide into position parallel to the magnet.
I created this because it was hard to adjust to the exact centre position of the arrow and needed to adjust different distances on the front and back of the clamp position. With this design the front and back are set to the same distance. The easiest way to set it up is to put an arrow in the jig, attach the clamp to the jig magnet. Loosen the front and back distance adjusting screws on the jig and hold it upside down allowing gravity to align the clamp to the arrow. Once it sits on the arrow slowly tighten the nobs and readjust if necessary and tighten it further until it is completely locked into position.

Printer:

Wombot Exilis

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

300 micron or less

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Suggesting to use CraftWare 1.14 to gnerate the G code. The support it generates is very easy to remove, unlike others.

Requirements

Make sure where the elastic touches the clamp does not have sharp edges. If it would then file these corners to round.

Construction

For the metal plate on the back you can use thicker than 1.5 mm or 1/16" steel plate. On the photos I used 2.5 mm which was cut from a right angle bracket I had at home. Make sure the metal plate is flat and there is no twist in it.
You can increase or decrease the clamping force by selecting the desired length, number and type of elastics you use for the clamp.
You can pull the elastic through by using either D-loop material or fishing line or some other usable thread.
With this clamp you can use up to 3 vanes on an arrow shaft. If you use the BPE Pro jig then set the nock angle to 90 degrees and the 3 vane positioning locks to 0, 120 and 240 degrees, see photo no 10. With the BPE Pro you can get up to 6 vanes on the arrow but with this design only up to 3 is recommended as the actual clamp would interfere with the other vanes already glued on the arrow shaft when getting to the last one.
(The original clamp is shown on one of the photos as well)

Usage

I personally like the fletching a bit closer to the nock as you can see it from the photos. You can add a spacer or add an extension to the design to increase the nock distance from the vanes if that is your preference.
Once you glued a vane in place, after the required amount of time for your particular glue, open the clamp by pinching the levers on the top together and lock it into the open position by sliding on the Clamp lock, see photo. Now you can rotate the arrow with the end nob to the next fletching position by turning it anti clockwise.

Recommended arrow rests

I never use whisker biscuit type arrow rests but they are suitable for this fletching.
I would recommend drop away arrow rests or
prog type launcher one like the Spot Hogg Premier or Infinity. Both come with a blade as well as the prog launcher so you can choose which one to install but I have not tested it with a blade type. I like the prog because I can adjust the distance between them.

I can mention I use igus drylins on my printer and (they might benefit from better bearingblocks than I have, that holds them a bit better) they seem quite sensisitive to twisting and if too much force is put on them. Most importantly for me the igus run very quietly... so nice!

title: Clicgear Holder for Large Sand Bottle

description.text:
Replaced by a better design www.thingiverse.com/thing:2512646

My golf course has typical large sand bottles of the sort you see attached to powered golf carts. I have a Clicgear pushcart and none of the Clicgear accessories I could find allowed me to carry one of the sand bottles on the cart attachment points. This design is in 6 pieces. The basic clip attaches to the cart. The rest of the holder is on a hinge so that the weight and forces don't easily break the clip. The holder itself had to be in 2 pieces (holder and arm) due to the size limits of my printer. They press fit together and the lockbar secures them together. The pin is forms the hinge and the hingepinlock insures the hinge pin doesn't slide out.

Creator Pro

print_settings.Notes:: 0.4mm Nozzle 1.2mm top/bottom and shell

description.text:
Prototype for a tube shaped two way satellite speaker. I printed it on my Cocoon Create (Wanhao Duplicator) in grey PLA but when I get to the "final design" I am considering using either Wood PLA or Carbon Fibre.

Note that the speaker is more geared to design and shape than sound quality but that said it did OK when I hooked it up to my Yamaha receiver. For drivers I used a 4" paper cone model which I bought at Jaycar (Australia) and the tweeter is one I salvaged from an old bookshelf speaker I had laying around. I am on the hunt for an affordable set of smaller black tweeters but unfortunately the hobby electronics market isn't what it once was so I will have to get something from China and redesign the tweeter enclosure when I get them. The filter is a very simple 1 capacitor and coil 1st order butterworth number that I soldered in place (as there is not enough space for a PCB)

It is my first attempt at this (and I am still very much a novice at 3D design) so please be kind :) I have identified some things that could be done differently so as I make changes I will update this post.

author: juicystarboy

description.text:
This is my model of a printable universal wrench that has the advantage of letting you carry a small set of wrenches in your pocket or bag.
It is suitable for nuts with sizes ranging from M1.6 up to M24, with a total of fourteen dimensions.

This model was made in Maya 2016.

First of all I designed the holes for the interior shape of the wrench, seven on each side of the wrench, the biggest two are in the middle and the others are in the six corners of the hexagon.

After that, I designed the exterior part of the wrench. The middle one is the biggest and it decreases in size with the size of the inner part. I used the ,,Difference,, command to get the seven wrench heads. After that I used the ,,Union,, command to combine them one by one. The middle one and the first one on the side. The second... The third... The fourth... The fifth... And the sixth one.

This project helped me discover the standardized size system used in industry.
As part of a physics club in high school, I discovered how useful working with tools is. The tool is a good ideea to provide a big number of students with a big number of dimensions of wrench without spending too much money and at the same time saving space because this tool does not need too much space.
Students will learn a variaty of skills, such us designing their tools using a 3D printer and also the basics abilities of building and disassembly. Due to the fact that this wrench is not made of metal, but plastic, it is much safer and suitable to be used by young children.
I designed this tool to be used in various areas, like science, physics, mechanical engineering

comments.text: You need some fillets on those inside corners. This is also a part you'd probably want to design in more of a solid cad program than a surface model program.

author: juicystarboy

print_settings.Notes:: Please look for a tight fit for the gears, there are multiple versions available.

description.text:
This is a 3D Printable Robot Arm. It may need a bit more time to build one, than your normal weekend Project. But the build process is one thing, the application environment the other. And that is what it is all about. Learning, combining and developing custom applications.
If you make a derivative, please only upload the parts you changed. Thanks.

Hardware

The design goal for me was to build a Robot, which is stiff and strong, but still small and easy to handle. I used the common NEMA17 Step Motors, which provide enough power for fast movements and high precision.
Almost every moveable joint has at least one ball bearing to reduce friction, overall stability and accuracy. The robot is designed to have a low center of mass.
The robot is powered over a Computer Power Supply (12V).

The gripper is easy to replace and is held horizontally in every position, which simplifies programming and also reduces the cost and complexity of additional axies.
Most parts have a industrial look like cast Iron parts.

Software

Software is now on Github here: https://github.com/ftobler/robotArm/

The control system uses an Arduino Mega with a RAMPS 1.4 Board and A4988 Drivers. I provide a solid and working programming base for the Arduino, which handles the Interpolation of the stepper motors, makes all geometric calculations and smooth accelerations. It can handle some sort of GCODE communication over Serial.

The software can be directly used without modifying or additional hardware like sensors can be added.
To get you started, I have a simple Interface for your Windows Computer, which has a sequencer and manual control options built in.

You should already have some decent programming skills to modify and use the Software. I am recommending this, because in my opinion programming is a key part of using a robot. Without it you can only scratch the surface of what's really possible.

Assembly

There are multiple versions of the big Gears. You may want to print them multiple times, if needed to reduce the gear slack of the rotational axis to a minimum. Depending on how high your Stepper Motor is, choose an appropriate leg height. Use Superglue to fix the bearings, if necessary. I have not cut any threads in the plastic. With PLA (maybe also others) you can 'melt' your thread through friction in, but you might want to drill the holes out a bit.

The Wiring of the Robot is not different from a 3D Printer that uses a RAMPS board. Use the official documentation: http://www.reprap.org/wiki/RAMPS_1.4

You can find details about the dimensions in 'doc2.pdf'

Video

I made a 3D animation, which gives you a good technical overview and a I show a simple application in another video.
Animation: https://youtu.be/-LztK9TKcZk
Actual Robot: https://youtu.be/HLlylJr_Vs4

Printer:

RF1000

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

about 15%

Notes:

Printed in clear PLA.

Please look for a tight fit for the gears, there are multiple versions available.

Turntable

One of the most critical parts of my design is the turntable. It uses multiple steel bearings.
A large thrust bearing is used to reduce flex in the design. Because 3D Printed parts are softer than metal, You might need bigger contact areas. The fully extended robot arm on top of it multiplies every gear and bearing tolerance you have.

the turntable is one of the most critical parts View of the large Thrust Bearing. Since it consists of loose parts There is a bolt and two more bearings. (Thrust Bearing 25x42x11mm (51105)) Base bearings detail view.

Drawings

detail drawing of the Robot. RobotArm is shown in Endstop Position Topology of an typical Robot Environment. The Robot normally is in the center of everything and every station/machine is aligned radially. This makes sense, because the robot rotates and can reach everything relatively easy. some of the small ball bearings I used. (Bearing 4x13x5mm (624zz) and Flanged Bearing 13x6x5mm (F686zz))

GCODE

A valid gcode command looks like G1 X0 Y120 Z120
There have to be spaces in between.

  • G0=G1: Move XYZ in mm (cartesian), F in mm/s. Always uses Absolute coordinates. Unlike 3D Printers, there is no E-Axis. On every move there is an acceleration and deacceleration.
  • G4: Dwell / Sleep T in milliseconds
  • M3: Close Gripper / Aux Motor T in Steps. Cannot move simultaneously to G
  • M5: Open Gripper / Aux Motor T in Steps. Cannot move simultaneously to G
  • M17: Enable Stepper Motors, also Enables Fan
  • M18: Disables Stepper Motors, also Disables Fan with delay
  • M106: Enables Fan
  • M106: Disables Fan

Desktop Software

I wrote a simple desktop application to control the robot. Clearly, this could be extended to a very big software project. So it provides only simple operations.

RobotArm_Software_v2.zip contains some bugfixes which includes some connection problems.

The software is written in Delphi

Softwareinterface

Nuts and Bolts

This is a rough count without warranty. I counted only the ones on the robot. So I recommend buying more than listed. Please add as much washers as needed, maybe buy different sizes. Washers and screws who are in contact to a bearing are only allowed to touch the inside rotary part.

  • 16x M3x6
  • 21x M3x8 (3x used as set screws)
  • 4x M3x10
  • 2x M3 Washer (large for gripper)

  • 4x M3 Nut

  • 6x M4x10
  • 11x M4x16
  • 2x M4x25
  • 14x M4 Washer (small enough for Bearing)

  • 8x M4 Nut

  • 12x M6 Washer (small enough for Bearing)
  • 3x M6 Nut
  • 3x M6 Self Locking Nut
  • 3x M6x45
  • 1x M6x80mm Threaded Rod

comments.text:
Hello?
We are Dongsan High School in Incheon, Korea.
We were also experiencing problems that many users face.
An error has occurred when I use it for awhile.
(Issues such as causing logs to occur, such as rx : k)
But we solved the problem by accident.
It might be a solution that could not be applied to everyone, but our solution was too simple.
It was just changing the Arduino board.
We use Arduino mega 2560, and we switch to a board using the ch340 chip, and it works perfectly.
I hope others solve the problem in this way.
Thank you very much. ftobler and devil502.
comments.author: DongsanHighSchool

comments.text: Thank you very much for that solution! Its now working without any issues. For everyone with the same communication problem: just buy a cheap arduino mega clone with the ch340 chip, download the drivers for the chip and it should work!

comments.text: That is intentional. More accurately every motor moves. That is because the robot extends out while rotating. You only changed X, so you have to adjust Y to have the same radius. In other words, the gripper follows a tangential line around the center.

comments.author: ramu114

comments.text: Had a look on it, and are having a hard time understanding the rrot and rside? What is the purpose of this?
comments.author: ftobler

comments.text:
both of these calculations use the Formula of Pythagoras:
rrot calculates the distance of the effector from the center, so It is just the radius from top view.
rside is practically the same from the side, but it uses rrot as parameter, so Its result is independent from the actual rotation of the robot. The resulting radius is the distance from center to the effector, like in a rotation independent side view.
comments.author: ramu114

description.text:
This is an enclosure for the common PIR sensor module, such as the one sold by Adafruit:

https://www.adafruit.com/product/189

It has a 20 degree downtilt. 3 lids are available, one with no side/top blinders, one with 5mm blinders and one with 10mm blinders. The blinders could be useful to avoid detection from areas other than directly ahead and below. A common use case for this would be to detect a person as they approach a door and trigger an electronic release.

title: Hexagonal Connectors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Time-lapse video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oOy8Z-Ftdmg

These are little hexagons that you can connect together. They work great for making art pieces, place mats, or showing young children how hexagons fit together.

I will add a picture of the printed model in about a week's time.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

2mm layer height

Infill:

50%

3D Design

I used OpenSCAD to make the model. I used for-loops for the connectors, and custom cylinders for the shapes.

Project Name

Hexagonal Connectors

Overview & Background

By completing this project, it can help kids to understand some basic geometry, and how hexagons relate. It can also be used as an art medium if printed in multiple colours

Objectives

Students would be expected to learn some basic geometry, like how hexagons relate, and how to be creative with shapes.

Audiences

This project was mostly intended for children at the elementary school level, but was also intended for anyone who just wants to create some art or put some blocks together.

Subjects

This would most definitely be an Art and Math project.

Skills Learned (Standards):

Some skills earned could be things like basic geometry understanding; creative thought; or math skills, if used as addition tiles.

Lesson/Activity
Group Build Activity
  1. Distribute pieces to all students or groups, depending on how many pieces you have
  2. Let them build for a set time
  3. Let students/groups share their design with the class
  4. Complete worksheet after (depending on age of the class) (may be substituted for class discussion)
  5. Done
Duration

15-45 mins depending on depth into activity, and student engagement. (print time not included)

Preperation

Print off pieces ahead of time. Preferably during class time, a few days in advance, so students can learn about how 3D printing really works.

References

As a post a post-activity, try making a simple sheet with questions or have a class discussion about the activity.

Rubric & Assessment

Students should have made some sort of artwork or shape out of the blocks, and have participated in class discussion or worksheet

title: Simple Adjustable Fan Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are a couple of simple joints that I designed to make positioning my fans accurately a little easier. I made these arms to fit the extruder I designed and so that I could keep using some fans I have gotten attached to, but should work just as well on other mounts.

The segments are all 4.5mm tall and has room for an M3 bolt to be sunk in 2.5mm. On the underside each has an M3 nut trap so it is easy to tighten two segments in place and lock a joint into position.The idea is to combine several segments into an adjustable arm that can be repositioned easily.

UPDATE 8/27/2016:
New version of this piece, it's a little taller for strength. I got rid of the pan head sinks and replaced them with hex traps, since most M3 bolts will fit in a hex trap just as easy. I also changed the lengths so that there weren't so many close in size.

Finally, I added a version where the hex traps are both on the same side, for navigating tricky clearance situations where you may not be able to use the other style.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Modified Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You could probably use less infill and get away with it, but the part is so small that it doesn't matter much either way. Fans are recommended if you want to avoid too much cleanup.

description.text: This is an scad file that will generate connectors for geodesic domes, hopefully.

My goal is to use this with tent poles, since it's fairly easy to come across a non-functional tent with lots of functional poles. According to http://www.desertdomes.com a 2v dome has 16 degrees on the pentagon (B struts) and 18degrees on 4 of the hexagons 6 with 16 degrees on two opposite ones. Checkout http://www.desertdomes.com/graphics/dome/2vdiagram.gif for assembly diagram. I've made a thru hole so you can bolt it with some 3mm bolt and big washers, I was having problems with it splitting where all the poles lineup. I also centered it.

description.text:
I had lots of trouble trying to get a dial indicator to mount to my Solidoodle carriage and give consistent readings of the bed level. I finally realized I shouldn't even try.  
This is a dial indicator mount that attaches directly to the X axis rails on a Solidoodle 2 (and maybe 3 if the rail separation is the same, but the openscad file is included for tweaking if you need to).  
I've experimented with this a little, and can't think of any more ways to improve it, so I'm calling it done now.

Print the railcrossing part. Make sure it fits snugly around the back rail and the front rail rests in the obvious position at the front of the railcrossing. You may need to file the back a bit before it fits properly (I didn't have to do much filing though). Note that the extra holes and crosshatch pattern are there simply to provide strain relief when printing the part (I had lots of trouble with it curling up). Drill or file the holes for the magnets till you can get a magnet to fit flush with the top of each hole (a small hole is provided in the bottom so you can push the magnet out after each test fitting with a toothpick or stiff wire). The back hole has a hole above it for running a drill bit through from the top. Epoxy magnets in each hole flush with the surface (the part is designed for the 1/4 inch cylindrical neodymium magnets which seem to be very popular, but the openscad source is available if you want to tweak the size of the magnet holes). Print the dialclamp part. Drill out the holes where the M3 bolt goes if it doesn't fit, and tap the hole on the other side of the clamp with an M3 tap (or use an M3 bolt with acetone on the threads, but I have a real M3 tap, so I used it). You could also modify the openscad source to put a M3 nut trap on the side if you have an M3 nut available. Note that when you put the dial indicator in the clamp, you want to tighten the nut just enough so the indicator can't move up, but not tight enough to crunch the plastic. After the epoxy has set, glue the dialclamp to the end of the railcrossing, and you should be ready to make bed measurements. That's just a theory, I haven't yet reached that point (my epoxy is curing as I write this). Hopefully I'll be able to get consistent results when measuring the same thing more than once. The magnets should hold the railcrossing solidly to the rails, and the dialclamp should hold the dial indicator solidly in position. More babbling about this can be found at http://tomhorsley.com/hardware/solidoodle/solidoodle-railmount.html.

author: marcelino

description.text:
Single - Inverted Style

Cap:
Drill a 1/4" hole in the cap of you favorite beverage & epoxy tubing into cap.

Tubing:
Used 1/4" Polyethylene tubing. Place a wire through tubing to get desired shape and heat in 212 degree water.

Flower:
Printed flower stem at 30% speed. Enlarge stem hole to 1/4" or more for a nice snug tubing fit and slide flower onto tubing.

Center Bushing:
Printed at 20% speed. Press bushing onto tubing & slide flower back.

Hanger:
Select appropriate size brackets and secure with string.

This style will leak when first inverted. Also leaks due to gravity, day/night temperature changes, sunlight/shade, solar flares, tides, black holes, etc. Best to keep out of direct sunlight to minimize leakage.

Clean up required. May scale for you needs.

DRIP CATCH SYSTEM: This design allows liquid to spill over and down to the next flower.
See parts layout image.

Catcher Flower:
Position under drip zone. Push tubing near the top to create a reservoir before spilling into the lower flower & glue. Printed stem at 40% speed.

Catcher & Bottle Counter Weight:
Printed at 60% speed, 80% infill,4,4,4 Scale Z axes to your needs. Clean hole with #14 drill bit.

Bottle Counter Weight:
For those who can't stand seeing things at an angle.

Tubing: A sharper bend will work better. Flower_landingV2 is designed to allow leakage. May glue the last outer flower.

Does you profile indicate where are you from? How about sharing your creation?

The original props were made by Bellbm, all  I did was fix them up.  
I do not recommend printing your own AR drone propellers. 
The AR flight controller is very sensitive, any imbalance and it can shut the craft down in mid air, so yeah - not a great experiment.
This fixes all the holes in the scanned prop that was uploaded. To get both sides, simply mirror this in replicatorG, this ended up being from the rear right prop after printing and fitting, so front left and rear right is this file, mirror for front right and rear left. Print with as little infill and shells as possible. If you have a digital scale, you are aiming for about 3.3grams per blade, if you are out, get sanding and balancing!  I used 3 percent infil and that was just enough to get them to hold, but they were still weak, this is going to be a long experiment.
