comments.text: Cool thanks for fixing the holes in the model.  I used SpaceClaim to make the model.  So if you need the native CAD model I have it.
comments.author: bellbm

comments.text: No need, but thank you. I use blender for all my modelling which imports .STL files just fine. I have been slowly fixing all the holes manually because Netfabb creates a very uneven surface when it does its autofix. I also needed to move the two outer poles slightly closer inward (1mm each side)  together as they do not fix the AR drones stock gears and snap if you try and force it.
comments.author: bellbm

title: Holder for glass print beds for FlashForge Creator or other 6"x9" printer

description.text:
Right now I have a Solidoodle 3 but my plan is to sell it and buy a FlashForge Creator.  The Solidoodle 3's print platform is 8"x8", while the FlashForge's is 6"x9".  This puts me in an interesting position: I can currently print something bigger than the print surface on my next printer, at least in one dimension.  Which is neat because normally the one thing you can't print on a printer is a holder for the print bed, because the holder has to be bigger than the print bed.  At least unless you have the Tardis 3000 printer.  
Thus, this is a simple storage bin for sheets of glass for a print bed, which I can print in one piece on the SD3.  I've designed this one with a slide-in shelf that lets me divide it into two bins, one for dirty glass and one for clean glass.

comments.text: I was never able to get this to print successfully on my SD3 before it left.  It was just too close to the maximum size.

author: chev383

description.text: This is an easy and fun math game to play with kids learning to do math. The purpose is to set an operation with the numbers and operators. Then the kid has to join the answer in his Result Base.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

I designed this Project using SolidWorks

I first conceived the idea, then I made a paper drawing plotting the idea in a more detailed way. Then I started the sketches in SolidWorks. Always taking into account the dimensions of the parts.

For the numbers I created a template with the maximum dimensions of the number. In there I only changed the actual number and the rest was automatically done. This helped save a lot of time.

THE ORDER OF THE FACTORS MATTERS. Always consider the way you design a part and make relations between dimensions. The order in which you perform operations is relevant in SolidWorks. Take into account possible reshapes or change in dimensions. If you don't do this you will have a real hard time modifying parts.

I always make an assembly of the final project in SolidWorks. Taking all the parts into the same layout helps to correct and see if there are any errors.

Note the way operations are performed on the left side. I use to perform extrudes, then cuts, and rectifying with fillets, chamfers, etc. at the end.

Project Name

Math Operation Game. Do Math in a fun and constructive way!

Overview and Background

This project aids in the teaching of math by performing operations like addition, substraction, division and multiplication in a fun way.

Objectives

Learn Basic Mathematical operations.

Audience

Kids in Elementary School who are beginning to learn Mathematics.
Ages: 5-10 aproximately

Subjects

Mathematics

Skills

Mathematical reasoning and logic.
Knowledge of mathematical operations
Knowledge of mathematical operators

Lesson/Activity

The Project is intended to be taught by an educator to a child learning Mathematics

-The educator sets the operation in the operation board.
-Gives the child the result base and numbers
-The child solves the problem and fills the result base with the number.
-The child joins the two bases, thus completing the operation.

Duration

Approximately 1-2 minutes per round.

A number of operations can be fixed in order to challenge students and determine who is the fastest in solving a set of operations.

Preparation

Prior basic Mathematical knowledge on numbers

description.text:
Figured I would share this gem I whipped up for the Seej game catapult that allows some adjustment to the trajectory of the projectile. I used the catapult and flag in a variation of Seej. You will want to print this in flexible filament.

Coincidentally, I made a video of printing these to show of my first use of BuildTak. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3o5gZPUBiHw

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed with red Ninjaflex.

comments.text: Does it need ninjaflex or can you use regular filament?
comments.author: skitcher

comments.text: You can use any filament; however, if it's a rigid filament (e.g. PLA) then slide it on before you glue the sides.
comments.author: skitcher
